content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This playground needs validation.

Well, this one certainly was a journey for me.. I didn't face any problem while implementing the memory part to the solver, but that scoring system took me a while.

End C++ solution (to replace tuple of strings): I encode every actions/requirements/optional req/ME req as a 32 bits integer. For the names and instruments I generate a map to convert them to integers and back to string when outputting the best solution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good conclusion to the Mrs Knuth series.
Enough changes to the previous part to justify another puzzle and the increase in the difficulty level.
The statement is clear and the tests/validators seem to cover everything.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: For non Pythoners quite challenge. But the sattisfaction is worth it

A minor suggestion would be to add numbers to the different parts of the score. That is: 1. Free Time, 2. Loud Instruments etc. I found myself many times going back and forth from the statement to the debug print, having to read a couple lines before finding where I was again.

(SPOILER) On another note I solved it in rust without using any `_remember` equivalent. It is just substantially slow for some tests, taking ~5secs for the entire test suite. The point being that I was not aware of this technique, and I don't think it is mentioned in the playground (other than in documentation of `_process_row_selection` in the python code).

Is there a simple problem/testsuite to implement this bit of logic? This puzzle has too many extra factors for me to delve on that part only.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I believe this one should belong to very hard difficulty.

I'll just leave it here and wait for upvotes. Maybe I'm wrong

Is your opinion based on the Algorithm X setup (multiplicity), or the evaluation of each potential schedule, or the challenge of translating the solver to Kotlin (adding memory)? Or maybe some of each or something else?

>> The point being that I was not aware of this technique,

When you say "this technique", are referencing adding memory to Algorithm X?

If that is true, my suggestion is to use the Mrs. Knuth Part III test suite, but don't process any solutions. Just count how many solutions are found and make sure you get all the same numbers of solutions with and without memory that are listed in the table on page 47 of the playground.
For all the Kotlin programmers, make sure to hit up @VizGhar with your Kotlin DLX questions! Outstanding job on the translation! Did you add memory to your solver?

Thank you! My next step is to add a few language translations to the end of the playground. If you have any interest in writing a PHP translation to my AlgorithmXSolver with @roboStac's DLX implementation, let me know!

Yes. I've added memory.

I don't believe any programmer will find it here but here is my repo with AlgoX implementation for Kotlin
https://github.com/VizGhar/Kotlin-DLX

I'll try to implement AlgoX in Java. Should be no brainer for me.
Ah, I'm so dumb, I went straight to 49 since that was the first Mrs. Knuth III title I found...

I've implemented this in Kotlin and AlgoX - DLX.

From previous puzzles, just adding multiplicity is really trivial but:

0. To write Kotlin implementation AlgoX is quite demanding
1. I ran out of time for validators 12 and up without implemented history = memoization required (automatically medium+)
2. with error this one might be debugging hell
3. input parsing and final evaluation is harder easy puzzle by itself

For me these 3 variables are too much for medium puzzle. I'd say this one is a lot  harder than "Thomas and the freight cars" (https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/thomas-and-the-freight-cars). So hard is lowest I can go

@VizGhar
How about Mrs. Knuth - Part II? Is its difficulty closer to Part I or closer to Part III?
Part II required only slight mental shift. I believe part II is a bit closer to I then it is to III. But maybe it's just me... We can wait for more inputs from other codingamers

@VizGhar I lean towards your reasoning. My suggestion is:
• Part I: Medium
• Part II: Medium
• Part III: Hard
I have updated this to hard.
